0.00.text:
Translator: Ken Harvey
Reviewer: Denise RQ

8.33.text: Everyone is in the middle of a life story,

11.90.text: and your story is being shaped

14.61.text:
by what you are saying yes to
and what you are saying no to.

19.23.text:
Your yeses and noes
are what boundaries are made of.

28.27.text:
How do we heal
when our boundaries are violated?

32.46.text: And how do we push through boundaries?

35.39.text:
These questions have been the center
of my life and my work.

39.66.text:
When I was a little kid,
and my world was just my family,

44.55.text:
we were the only ones struggling
with those questions.

48.14.text:
And then I grew up,
and I became a family therapist.

52.56.text:
And I saw lots of people struggling
with these questions.

55.83.text:
And when I took a detour
and ran nonprofits,

59.54.text:
I saw communities and leaders
struggling with these questions.

65.12.text: So now I teach workshops and wrote a book

67.91.text: to help people answer these questions.

71.02.text:
And as people answer these questions
and learn more about their boundaries,

75.64.text:
I've watched hundreds of people
make the journey

78.09.text:
from being overwhelmed,
and exhausted, and stressed out

84.77.text:
and are decisive, and are committed
to healthy relationships.

89.91.text:
I'm going to share some stories
and some tools

92.97.text:
that you can use
to strengthen your boundaries.

96.75.text:
Let's begin with the most essential
boundary tool that everyone has.

103.93.text:
Take a moment and visualize
a compass in your hand.

110.11.text:
It has two words on it, yes and no,
and only those two words.

116.10.text:
You use this compass
to make your decisions,

120.62.text:
and set your boundaries
for your whole life.

123.84.text:
Today I'm going to talk about
how you can use this compass

126.82.text:
to place boundaries
where you need them the most,

130.52.text:
lower your stress,
and figure out your life's purpose.

135.37.text:
Now the key to placing boundaries
where you need them the most

143.34.text: I was raised by my grandparents,

146.61.text:
and my grandfather had one way
of doing things: his way.

152.88.text: And when I was 24, he came to me,

154.99.text:
and he asked me
to be the executor of his will.

158.00.text:
And I asked him, "What was it
he wanted me to do after he died?"

162.56.text:
And when he told me,
I got all this stress inside

165.95.text:
because there were things
I didn't want to do

168.06.text: to other family members on his behalf.

172.63.text: And I really wanted to please him,

174.65.text: but I couldn't say yes to all this stuff.

177.98.text:
So I told him, "No,"
I couldn't be his executor.

182.07.text:
And he did what most people do
when you tell them no.

188.97.text:
You know, when you listen
to your own yes and no,

192.28.text:
other people are going to get angry,
or they may get disappointed.

202.86.text: and yes and no are not feelings.

205.93.text:
So I couldn't let my fear
of my grandfather's anger

209.24.text:
nor my desire to please him
determine my boundaries.

214.51.text:
Now, sometimes,
your compass is clouded over,

218.91.text:
and you can't see if something
is a yes or a no for you,

222.39.text:
and this happens
if you've been ignoring your compass

225.84.text:
or arguing with it
because you don't like what it's saying.

230.14.text: Years ago, I wanted to be a writer,

233.08.text:
and I was very busy working,
and I couldn't figure out

235.92.text:
how writers made time to write
and earn a living.

240.51.text:
So I took this yes,
and I shoved it to the side.

243.83.text: Those are the writers that are here.

249.16.text:
And my daughters and I
were attending this writing camp,

256.34.text: and I got to go as a chaperone.

258.54.text:
And one night,
this real writer got on the stage,

261.95.text: and he told us how he made time to write,

264.41.text:
what he said yes to with his time
and what he said no to

268.15.text: in order to complete his books.

270.40.text:
He lived very cheaply,
and his sole job was writing.

278.12.text: So for two years I saved my money,

280.73.text:
I lowered my expenses,
and then, when the time came,

284.54.text:
when I had my money saved up,
I devoted myself to writing.

293.45.text:
All that work, and in, like,
just a few short months,

300.72.text:
Writing is a solo sport;
you sit alone all day.

306.85.text: There I was, talking to my dog.

310.96.text:
"Oh, this is not the move for me;
I'm a people person."

314.47.text: So I listened to my no.

316.50.text: I went back to working with people,

319.00.text: and I saved some of my time for writing.

321.68.text: That was a much better fit.

324.19.text: Now if you pay attention to this compass,

327.43.text:
it just gives you the basic guidance,
the yes and the no.

331.55.text: It doesn't give you any details.

334.06.text: You have to figure out the details.

336.70.text:
But the thing is,
you can trust this compass,

339.35.text: because it's only trying to do one thing,

342.88.text: and that's take care of you.

345.50.text:
And if you allow your compass
and your boundaries to take care of you,

350.19.text:
it'll mitigate stress,
and stress is a very serious issue.

355.02.text:
According to
the American Psychological Association,

358.60.text:
50 to 58% of us
- I'm not going to say who --

366.62.text: That's kind of a shocking number.

368.46.text:
And employers who are listening
may want to pay attention to this

371.58.text:
and think about how important is
decision making on the job,

376.56.text:
because this compass
is highly sensitive to stress,

382.08.text: and stress clouds over your compass.

388.48.text:
so that they can reduce and prevent
their stress from accumulating.

395.44.text:
is that setting boundaries
is just a little stressful.

405.74.text:
Like, once you get over
that brief stress of actually doing it,

412.15.text: and I call that brief stress "sweating".

415.24.text:
You're going to do a little sweating
when you set your boundaries.

418.46.text: I sweat, and I teach this stuff.

422.13.text:
So let's go back
to this compass in your hand

425.34.text: that is only trying to take care of you

431.62.text:
are there ways
that you could improve your self-care?

439.02.text:
And when I say self-care,
many of you may think first

442.59.text:
about what you eat
and how much you exercise,

447.09.text: but even people who do those really well

449.75.text:
are going to have high stress
if they aren't managing their boundaries.

455.15.text:
Self-care is a much bigger landscape
than eating and exercise.

460.19.text: Self-care is how you treat yourself.

463.16.text: It's how you find enjoyment, play,

474.20.text:
I'm the first to admit, though,
that self-care can be really hard,

478.68.text:
and it took me a long time
to learn how to do it.

482.79.text: In the past, and I like saying "past",

488.67.text: And back then, I was running an agency

491.59.text: that was serving teens who were homeless.

494.98.text:
It was an agency that I started,
and I was deeply committed to.

500.70.text:
And over the years,
as the organization grew,

503.49.text: it needed more and more from me.

507.46.text:
So what if I was up night after night
trying to make that budget work?

512.18.text: - and I couldn't, a lot of the time.

516.18.text:
So what if I was on call
7 days a week, 24 hours a day,

526.70.text:
So what if I was getting sick
from watching so much child abuse?

532.06.text:
So what if I actually had
post-traumatic stress from it?

539.55.text:
until one day, I was sitting
in this dark movie theater,

543.93.text: and I was crying and crying.

546.94.text: I broke; I couldn't stop crying,

551.17.text:
and I realized something inside
was trying to reach me.

555.46.text: And as I listened to my tears,

558.10.text:
I understood that I couldn't
keep running this organization

562.72.text: that I started and that I loved.

566.73.text:
My compass was saying no
for my well-being.

572.36.text: That was really hard to take.

574.40.text:
My well-being, up against
all these kids who needed help?

579.06.text:
So I dug deep with my compass
about my purpose.

583.50.text:
And I understood that maybe it had been
my purpose to start the organization,

591.20.text:
the community loved
and could care for this organization.

597.93.text:
And so I spent a year
with my board of directors,

601.05.text:
and we transitioned leadership
to new leaders for the organization.

606.82.text:
And I want to tell you
it's still standing, 24 years now,

611.02.text: taking care of kids every day--

622.32.text:
doing exactly what it was designed to do,
the way it was designed to do it.

629.04.text: And I learned from my compass

631.17.text:
that other people
could take care of the kids,

634.65.text: and the staff, and the organization,

638.80.text: but only I could take care of me.

642.04.text: And then I had to face my workaholic.

649.24.text:
My workaholic, she's terrifying;
she's worse than my grandfather.

655.54.text:
My workaholic never says,
"Oh, take a break. You've done enough."

664.77.text:
And she just keeps going
and going and going.

667.68.text:
And I had to intervene
with some care for me.

670.86.text: And my care for me got better and better,

674.76.text: year after year, step by step.

678.23.text:
Now I challenge myself every day
to do some of my work

683.06.text:
and then do something that I love,
that I can fit into each day.

687.62.text:
So I knit more,
I hang out with my friends.

690.80.text:
My friends are kind of shocked
that I have time for them.

694.16.text: My husband and I, we do less chores,

696.98.text: and we just have more fun.

701.26.text:
are in this ongoing conversation
about healthy living,

704.90.text:
as they both grew up
and went into healthcare.

710.18.text: And this summer, on a hot sunny day,

713.26.text:
I was watching this eagle
soaring overhead at the beach.

717.75.text: I remember everything about this day.

720.73.text: It was a Tuesday, a work day.

727.05.text:
I drove four minutes
from my office to the beach.

730.72.text:
And there I was,
taking a 45-minute lunch break,

734.27.text:
watching this eagle
and listening to the waves.

742.71.text: Now I need to warn you.

744.75.text:
Even if you're doing
all the boundary pieces,

747.01.text:
like, you -- you've separated
your feelings from your boundaries,

752.52.text: and you're doing some good self-care,

756.27.text:
and you're really listening
to your yes and no,

758.93.text:
and maybe you've recovered
from workaholism or numbing out;

764.22.text:
even when you do all these pieces
really, really well,

767.40.text: there are going to be some things

769.38.text:
that are going to challenge
your boundaries,

771.63.text:
and they're going
to make things extra hard.

776.05.text: None of us are immune to health issues,

784.40.text:
or to a family member
who has an addiction problem.

788.11.text:
And some of you are dealing
with those struggles every day.

792.56.text:
Some of you are dealing
with really tough challenges

798.13.text:
There are three things that you can do
to support your compass.

804.24.text:
You may already be doing some self-care,
but you need to step it up.

809.19.text:
When your loved one has breast cancer,
what I always see is

813.77.text:
your care for you goes down
while you care for someone else.

818.92.text: And taking that time to care for yourself

821.88.text:
may seem completely ridiculous
in the face of such a big challenge.

826.77.text: But I want to see the care for you go up

828.80.text: while you care for someone else

831.40.text:
so that you're a stronger support
in the long run for you and for them.

837.87.text:
The second thing to do is to reach out
and build a web of resources.

842.62.text:
Your compass may not have
enough information to guide you

846.25.text:
through the challenge
that you're dealing with.

848.55.text:
We're not all experts in everything;
find people who have this expertise.

854.02.text: Join a support group, see a therapist,

860.87.text:
The third thing to do is to really focus
on choosing your responsibilities

866.48.text: and limiting your time during a challenge.

870.18.text:
During a challenge, we have,
like, tons of extra responsibilities

873.84.text:
just coming down the hill at us,
and you can't do it all.

878.15.text:
You have to decide what you will
and won't be responsible for,

881.31.text:
and you have to let go
of some of the rest.

885.34.text:
And nowadays, our technology
has created this illusion

890.72.text:
that you are all a device
that is always on.

896.21.text:
And now more than ever, you need
to be careful and be protective

900.13.text:
so that you have some time
to recover during a big challenge,

904.33.text:
and times when you're not doing
ongoing problem-solving.

910.92.text:
All of you are
in the middle of a life story,

915.29.text: and your story is being shaped

918.30.text:
by what you are saying yes to
and what you are saying--

925.67.text:
Sarri Gilman: If you shut out
the noise and listen,

928.60.text:
you're going to find yourself
going through life with less stress

933.75.text: and profoundly in tune with your purpose.
